etri.sdn.controller.module.linkdiscovery

Class OFMLinkDiscovery

  • java.lang.Object
    • etri.sdn.controller.OFModule
      • etri.sdn.controller.module.linkdiscovery.OFMLinkDiscovery
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IService, ILinkDiscoveryService

    public class OFMLinkDiscovery
extends OFModule
implements ILinkDiscoveryService
    Link Discovery Module. This module implements ILinkDiscoveryService. This service is used by OFMTopologyManager.
    Author:
    bjlee

    • Field Detail

      • LLDP_STANDARD_DST_MAC_STRING

        private static final byte[] LLDP_STANDARD_DST_MAC_STRING
        LLDP Data Units (LLDPDUs) are sent to the destination MAC address 01:80:c2:00:00:0e. This address is defined as the "LLDP_Multicast" address. This address is defined within a range of addresses reserved by the IEEE for protocols that are to be constrained to an individual LAN. AN LLDPDU will not be forwarded by MAC bridges (e.g. switches) that conform to IEEE Std 802.1D-2004.

      • LLDP_TO_KNOWN_INTERVAL

        protected final int LLDP_TO_KNOWN_INTERVAL
        LLDP frequency for known links. This value is intentionally kept higher than LLDP_TO_ALL_INTERVAL. If we want to identify link failures faster, we could decrease this value to a small number, say 1 or 2 sec.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • sendDiscoveryMessage

        private boolean sendDiscoveryMessage(IOFSwitch sw,
                           int port,
                           boolean isStandard,
                           boolean isReverse)
        Send link discovery message out of a given switch port. The discovery message may be a standard LLDP or a modified LLDP, where the dst mac address is set to :ff. TODO: The modified LLDP will updated in the future and may use a different eth-type.
        Parameters:
        sw -
        port -
        isStandard - indicates standard or modified LLDP
        isReverse - indicates whether the LLDP was sent as a response
        Returns:
        return false value if we cannot send discovery message to output stream to switch

      • handleHandshakedEvent

        protected boolean handleHandshakedEvent(Connection conn,

        An abstract method that all subclasses should implement. This method is called after FEATURE-REQUEST and FEATURE-REPLY is correct exchanged, by OFModule.processHandshakeFinished(Connection, MessageContext).       • handlePacketIn

        private boolean handlePacketIn(IOFSwitch sw,
                     MessageContext context,
                     org.openflow.protocol.interfaces.OFPacketIn pi,
                     java.util.List<org.openflow.protocol.OFMessage> outgoing)
        This method handles a PACKET_IN message as follows:
        1. First, decapsulate the Ethernet part of the PACKET_IN payload.
        2. if the ETHERTYPE of the header is BSN and its payload is LLDP, that means a BDDP packet (non-standard bigswitch-specific LLDP) is received. If not, just return true to pass this PACKET_IN to other module. The BDDP packet is handled by calling handleLldp(LLDP, IOFSwitch, OFPacketIn, boolean, List).
        3. If the ETHERTYPE of the header is LLDP, then handle the packet by calling handleLldp(LLDP, IOFSwitch, OFPacketIn, boolean, List).
        4. If the ETHERTYPE of the header is smaller than (<) 1500 and destMac & LINK_LOCAL_MASK) == LINK_LOCAL_VALUE, then we just return false to suppress the further processing of the PACKET_IN msg.
        However, in the current OFMLinkDiscovery Implementation, As initialize() has been coded only to accept the standard LLDP packets with Ethertype 0x88cc, there are other cases that never be executed.
        Parameters:
        sw - IOFSwitch object
        context - MessageContext object
        pi - packet-in message
        outgoing - messages to send to switch in result
        Returns:
        true if correctly handled

      • handleLldp

        private boolean handleLldp(LLDP lldp,
                 IOFSwitch sw,
                 org.openflow.protocol.interfaces.OFPacketIn pi,
                 boolean isStandard,
                 java.util.List<org.openflow.protocol.OFMessage> outgoing)
        From the LLDP packet received, this method first extract following information:
        1. remote switch information
        2. controller id (if this message is created by a controller)
        3. direction of the message
        The business logic of this method are as follows:
        1. if the message is a standard LLDP which is not created by this controller, then drop it.
        2. if the message is a non-standard LLDP which is not created by this controller, then return true to allow the further processing. (maybe forwarding?)
        3. if the remote switch or one of the sides of the link port is not enabled, then drop it.
        4. or, call Links#addOrUpdateLink(long, short, OFPhysicalPort, long, int, OFPhysicalPort, boolean, boolean), remove the node & port pair (both side) from the Quarantine and Maintenance Queue and drop the message.
        Parameters:
        lldp - LLDP packet to process
        sw - the switch that the lldp packet is received
        pi - OFPacketIn message itself
        isStandard - true(standard LLDP), or false
        outgoing - list of OFMessage objects to be delivered to switches after this method ends the execution
        Returns:
        true to further process the message, or false.

      • handlePortStatus

        private boolean handlePortStatus(IOFSwitch sw,
                       MessageContext context,
                       org.openflow.protocol.interfaces.OFPortStatus ps,
                       java.util.List<org.openflow.protocol.OFMessage> outgoing)
        Handle PORT_STATUS message.
        1. if the PORT_STATUS message shows that a link has been deleted or modified where the port is down or configured down, we mark the link has been deleted by calling Links.deleteLinksOnPort(NodePortTuple).
        2. or if the PORT_STATUS indicates that the status of a link has been changed, we mark the link has been changed by calling Links.updatePortStatus(Long, int, OFPortStatus).
        3. and finally, if a link has NOT been deleted, we process the PORT_STATUS as an indication that a new port has been added, by calling processNewPort(IOFSwitch, int).
        Parameters:
        sw - IOFSwitch object
        context - MesasgeContext object
        ps - OFPortStatus object
        outgoing - messages to send to switch in result
        Returns:
        true if correctly handled, false otherwise
